name: Common Viper
description: The common viper is a relatively small snake, typically around 50 cm, never exceeding a meter. Except for entirely black individuals in mountainous areas, it has a dark 'zigzag' line on its back.
spread_note: Most of Europe (except the Iberian Peninsula, Italy, Ireland, Greece, and northern Scandinavia), east through western and Central Asia to Korea and Sakhalin
image_alt: Common Viper, photo: Thomas H Brown
proportions: Length 50−80 (max. 100) cm, about 13% tail, weight 80−120 g
reproduction: Viviparous—gestation lasts 4−6 months, averages 7 (up to 12) young.
attractions: The common viper is our only venomous snake—known and unjustly feared. It avoids humans whenever possible.
breeding: Since spring 2014, you can find the common viper at the Zakázanka trail exhibit linking the zoo’s upper and lower parts.
